Description: Fragment of a massive basin, more specifically sha-basin, carved from dark grey basalt; figure of plumed Bes in relief and incised demotic text on the outer surface; damaged human figure on the top, remains only of the feet (priest or dedicant?); shallow basin (start of bottom visible).
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie (probably)
Curator's comments: Sha-basins are ritual basins (Wörterbuch der ägyptischen Sprache vol. IV, 1971, 401, 2) particularly typical of the Ptolemaic period (Yoyotte 1994-95, 674). Petrie mentioned this basin in his diary: 'A very interesting find made lately in the later period (Roman) chambers built inside the temenos wall, is a fragment of a black basalt bowl some 2 or 3 feet diam[eter] & 3 or 4 in[che]s deep. Bes standing on the outer face, & a line of demotic, & on the top edge the feet of a standing figure: another fragment with more demotic was found later on.' (Petrie diary 1884-1885, p. 97-98). The dedication is made in honour of the main Egyptian god revered in Naukratis, Amun-Ra Baded. The representation of Bes is rare on sha-basin, usually of a Hathor head. Found to the north side of the Great Temenos (“inner side of north wall”) On this sha-basin, see: Petrie 1886, 34, pl. XXXVI, 6; Gardner 1888, 81, pl. XXIII, 6; Yoyotte 1982-83, 133, no. 5; Yoyotte 1994-95, 674 (with wrong ref. to Gardner 1888), 675; Vleeming 2001, 242-243, no. 269; Guermeur 2005, 131. Gardner, E. A. 1888, Naukratis.
